name: Generate Accessible Alt Text with AI from Google Sheets to WordPress
description:
# AI-powered alt text generation from Google Sheets to WordPress media
## Who's it for
WordPress site owners, content managers, and accessibility advocates who need to efficiently add alt text descriptions to multiple images for better SEO and web accessibility compliance.
## What it does
This workflow automates the process of generating and updating alt text for WordPress media files using AI analysis. It reads image URLs from a Google Sheet, analyzes each image with Claude AI to generate accessibility-compliant descriptions, updates the sheet with the generated alt text, and automatically applies the descriptions to the corresponding WordPress media files. The workflow includes error handling to skip unsupported media formats and continue processing.
## How it works

Input: Provide a Google Sheets URL containing image URLs and WordPress media IDs
Authentication: Retrieves WordPress credentials from a separate sheet and generates Base64 authentication
Processing: Loops through each image URL in the sheet
AI Analysis: Claude AI analyzes each image and generates concise, accessible alt text (max 125 characters)
Error Handling: Automatically skips unsupported media formats and continues with the next item
Update Sheet: Writes the generated alt text back to the Google Sheet
WordPress Update: Updates the WordPress media library with the new alt text via REST API

## Requirements

Google Sheets with image URLs and WordPress media IDs
WordPress site with Application Passwords enabled
Claude AI (Anthropic) API credentials
WordPress admin credentials stored in Google Sheets
Export Media URLs WordPress plugin for generating the media list

## How to set up
### Step 1: Export your WordPress media URLs

Install the "Export Media URLs" plugin on your WordPress site
Go to the plugin settings and check both ID and URL columns for export (these are mandatory for the workflow)
Export your media list to get the required data

### Step 2: Configure WordPress Application Passwords

Go to WordPress Admin → Users → Your Profile
Scroll down to "Application Passwords" section
Enter application name (e.g., "n8n API")
Click "Add New Application Password"
Copy the generated password immediately (it won't be shown again)

### Step 3: Set up Google Sheets
[Duplicate this Google Sheets template](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1BKGQRx_xDiuh3QD3ACOOTJomsWFuPBjCHYMQX8UzTBE/edit?usp=sharing\) to get the correct structure.
The template includes two sheets:
Sheet 1: "Export media" - Paste your exported media data with columns:

ID (WordPress media ID)
URL (image URL)
Alt text (will be populated by the workflow)

Sheet 2: "Infos client" - Add your WordPress credentials:

Admin Name: Your WordPress username
KEY: The application password you generated
Domaine: Your site URL without https:// (format: "example.com")

### Step 4: Configure API credentials

Add your Anthropic API credentials to the Claude node
Connect your Google Sheets account to the Google Sheets nodes

## How to customize

Language: The Claude prompt is in French - modify it in the "Analyze image" node for other languages
Alt text length: Adjust the 125-character limit in the Claude prompt
Batch processing: Change the batch size in the Split in Batches node
Error handling: The workflow automatically handles unsupported formats, but you can modify the error handling logic
Authentication: Customize for different WordPress authentication methods

This workflow is perfect for managing accessibility compliance across large WordPress media libraries while maintaining consistent, AI-generated descriptions. It's built to be resilient and will continue processing even when encountering unsupported media formats.

nodes.name: Get WP Key + website URL WITHOUT https://

parameters.url: =https://{{ $('Get WP Key + website URL WITHOUT https://').item.json.Domaine }}/wp-json/wp/v2/media/{{ $('Loop Over Items').item.json.ID }}

parameters.text:
#Tâche 
Analysez cette image et rédigez une description alternative (alt text) pour l'accessibilité web.
Critères :

##Caractéristiques
Maximum 125 caractères
Décrire les éléments visuels essentiels
Ton neutre et factuel
Commencer par l'élément principal

Inclure : sujet principal, actions significatives, contexte important, texte visible
Éviter : "image de", "photo de", détails décoratifs, interprétations
Réponse : Fournir uniquement la description, sans guillemets.

##Exemples

Incorrect : Photo d'un chat mignon qui dort sur un canapé rouge dans un salon
Correct : Chat tigré dormant sur un canapé rouge

parameters.content: # Phase 1: Webhook Initialization

### What you do:

Send the Google Sheets URL containing image data to the webhook endpoint
Trigger the workflow by providing the spreadsheet link
Ensure the spreadsheet contains "Export media" and "Infos client" sheets

### What the system does:

Receives the Google Sheets URL via webhook trigger
Initializes the workflow with the provided spreadsheet link
Prepares the system for data retrieval and processing
Sets up public webhook endpoint for easy access

### Result:
✅ Workflow activated with your specific spreadsheet
✅ Secure webhook connection established
✅ System ready to process image data
✅ Easy triggering mechanism available
# Phase 2: Client Configuration Retrieval

### What the system does:

Connects to the "Infos client" sheet in your Google Sheets document
Retrieves WordPress credentials including admin name and API key
Extracts domain information for WordPress site access
Prepares authentication data for WordPress API integration

### Result:
✅ WordPress site credentials obtained
✅ Domain information retrieved for API calls
✅ Client-specific configuration loaded
✅ Foundation established for WordPress integration
# Phase 3: Authentication Setup

### What the system does:

Processes WordPress credentials from the client information
Generates Base64 encoded authentication using username and API key
Creates authorization header for WordPress REST API calls
Prepares secure authentication for image updates

### Result:
✅ Secure WordPress API authentication configured
✅ Base64 encoding completed for credentials
✅ Authorization headers prepared
✅ API access permissions established
# Phase 4: Image URL Collection

### What the system does:

Reads the "Export media" sheet from your Google Sheets
Extracts all image URLs and associated metadata
Retrieves image IDs for WordPress integration
Prepares dataset for alt text processing

### Result:
✅ Complete image inventory collected
✅ WordPress media IDs retrieved
✅ Image URLs organized for processing
✅ Data structure prepared for analysis
# Phase 4.5: Empty Alt Text Filtering

### What the system does:

Filters images to identify those missing alt text descriptions
Excludes images that already have alt text content
Creates focused dataset of images needing descriptions
Optimizes processing by targeting only necessary items

### Result:
✅ Only images without alt text selected
✅ Efficient resource utilization achieved
✅ Processing time optimized
✅ Duplicate work prevention implemented
# Phase 5: Sequential Image Processing

### What the system does:

Processes each image without alt text one at a time
Maintains data integrity throughout the iteration
Prepares individual images for AI analysis
Ensures systematic handling of all qualifying images

### Result:
✅ Organized processing of all target images
✅ Sequential handling prevents system overload
✅ Data consistency maintained
✅ Scalable processing approach implemented
# Phase 6: AI-Powered Alt Text Generation

### What the system does:

Analyzes each image using GPT-4O-mini vision capabilities
Generates descriptive alt text following accessibility best practices
Applies specific guidelines for maximum 125 characters
Creates factual, neutral descriptions focusing on essential visual elements
Follows SEO and accessibility standards for web content

### Result:
✅ Professional alt text generated for each image
✅ Accessibility standards compliance achieved
✅ Consistent quality and tone maintained
✅ SEO-optimized descriptions created
# Phase 7: Error Handling Validation

### What the system does:

Checks AI analysis results for any processing errors
Validates successful alt text generation before proceeding
Handles failed analyses by continuing with other images
Ensures workflow stability despite individual processing issues

### Result:
✅ Error resilience built into the system
✅ Failed analyses don't stop the workflow
✅ Quality control implemented
✅ Reliable processing guaranteed
# Phase 8: Spreadsheet Update

### What the system does:

Updates the Google Sheets with generated alt text
Matches URLs to ensure correct image association
Populates the "Alt text" column with AI-generated descriptions
Maintains data synchronization between systems

### Result:
✅ Generated alt text saved to spreadsheet
✅ Data integrity maintained across systems
✅ Progress tracking enabled
✅ Backup of generated content created
# Phase 9: WordPress Integration

### What the system does:

Connects to WordPress REST API using authenticated credentials
Updates each media item with the generated alt text
Uses WordPress media ID for precise targeting
Applies alt text directly to the WordPress media library

### Result:
✅ Alt text automatically applied to WordPress images
✅ Media library updated with accessibility content
✅ SEO improvements implemented on live site
✅ WordPress integration completed seamlessly

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.

data.details: The Code node allows you to execute JavaScript in your workflow.

The Filter node can be used to filter items based on a condition. If the condition is met, the item will be passed on to the next node. If the condition is not met, the item will be omitted. Conditions can be combined together by AND(meet all conditions), or OR(meet at least one condition).
